data.comment: <2010.10.12> The text to use when displaying a gallery's description. Ex: "Gallery 'My Gallery'" The first placeholder is replaced by a link to the gallery; the second is replaced by the gallery's description.

data.name: Admin_Gallery_Settings_Cannot_Display_Account_Edit_Link_Msg
data.value: WARNING: When the header is hidden, Gallery Server cannot display the link to allow users to manage their own account. To keep the link visible, enable the header and turn off individual header controls to achieve the desired effect.

data.name: Admin_Gallery_Control_Settings_ShowAlbumTreeViewForAlbum_Label
data.value: Show left pane when an album is being shown

data.name: Admin_Gallery_Control_Description_Label
data.value: The Gallery user control '{0}' on page '{1}'

data.name: Admin_Gallery_Settings_Change_Gallery_Tooltip
data.value: Associate the selected gallery with this web page

data.name: Admin_Gallery_Control_Settings_ShowAlbumTreeViewForMediaObject_Label
data.value: Show left pane when a single media asset is being shown

data.name: Admin_Cannot_Delete_Role_Insufficient_Permission_Msg
data.value: The role '{0}' has access to a gallery (Gallery '{1}') that you are not an administrator for. To delete a role, one of the following must be true: (1) you are a site administrator, or (2) you are a gallery administrator in every gallery the role has access to.

data.name: Admin_Cannot_Delete_Role_Remove_Self_Admin_Msg
data.value: You are attempting to delete a role that would remove or restrict your level of administrative access. If you really want to do this, log on as another user and make the changes from that account.

data.name: Admin_Manage_Roles_Cannot_Delete_Role_Insufficient_Permission_Msg
data.value: You must be a site administrator to save changes to a role with Administer site permission. Sadly, you are just a gallery administrator.

data.name: Admin_Manage_Roles_Cannot_Delete_Role_Insufficient_Permission_Msg2
data.value: You are attempting to save changes to a role that affects at least one gallery you do not have permission to administer. To edit this role, you must be one of the following : (1) a site administrator, or (2) a gallery administrator in every gallery this role applies to.

data.name: Admin_Gallery_Settings_CurrentGallery_Info_Bdy
data.value:
Here you can change the gallery the current instance of Gallery Server points to.

A gallery has these charecteristics:

  • Contains a collection of albums and media assets that are stored at or below a particular file path
  • Has a distinct set of settings, such as watermark, image size, user settings, etc.
  • Can be managed by a gallery or site administrator

By default, each web application has one gallery. This is sufficient for many users, but there are situations where it can be useful to have more than one gallery:

  • You want to have one gallery for staging and another for production.
  • You have departments in your company that should each have their own gallery.
  • You have media files in multiple locations you want to expose, such as D:\Pictures and D:\Video.
  • You want to set up a gallery for each member of your family.
  • You want some images to be 640x480 and others to be smaller (or larger).
  • You require different watermarks to be applied to different sets of images.
  • You want to provide a user with different gallery-wide permissions. For example, perhaps you want user Bob to be a gallery administrator for one set of assets but have edit-only permission for another set.
  • You want to allow some users to upload any file type of any size, but others should only be able to upload .JPEG files that are less than 5 MB.

Note that if all you want to do is hide albums from certain users, you can use roles and an album's privacy setting rather than creating a new gallery.

Viewing multiple galleries

Each instance of the Gallery Server control is associated with a single gallery. To view multiple galleries, you must create additional web pages and point those instances of Gallery Server to the new gallery. One easy way to do this is to copy the web page containing this control, give it a new name, then load the page in a web browser, navigate to the Gallery Manager and point it to the new gallery.

data.name: Admin_Gallery_Settings_ManageGalleries_Info_Bdy
data.value:
Add, edit or delete galleries for the current web application. The table displays only those galleries where the currently logged on user is a gallery administrator.

You can view the contents of the current gallery with the View link. To view other galleries, first switch to that gallery in the Current Gallery section.

Clicking the Edit link allows you to change the name of the gallery. To modify other settings, such as the media files path, use the appropriate administration page.

Deleting a gallery will delete all albums, media assets, and other records associated with the gallery. As a safety precaution, the media files are NOT deleted - only the records in the database are deleted. You may delete the media files manually using a tool like File Explorer.

The Create gallery link creates a new gallery, including a default set of gallery settings. After creating a gallery, one of the first things you should do is update the media files path on the Media Settings page.

data.name: Cfg_GCS_AllowAnonBrowsing_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies whether users can browse the gallery without logging in. When unchecked, users must log in with a valid account to view media assets.

Remember that this setting applies only to the instance of Gallery Server on this web page. If an administrator created other web pages with a gallery, this setting does not apply to them.

data.name: Cfg_GCS_AllowUrlOverride_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies whether an album or media asset specified in the URL can override the default gallery asset specified above. Since this is the means by which most album and media asset navigation occurs in Gallery Server, disabling this option prevents the user from viewing any album or media asset other than the one specified as the default gallery asset.

When unchecked, hyperlinks are not rendered on thumbnail images or the album breadcrumb menu.

Another way to prevent users from viewing albums or media assets is to set an album as private (for anonymous users) or use role permissions (for logged on users).

NOTE: This setting DOES NOT affect the ability of a user to click the Next / Previous buttons that appear above a single media asset. To disable this type of navigation, disable the option below named Show next/previous buttons for media assets.

data.name: Cfg_GCS_AutoPlaySlideshow_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies whether a slideshow of images automatically starts playing when the page loads.

An album must contain at least one image for a slideshow to run.

data.name: Cfg_GCS_DefaultGalleryObject_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies which gallery asset to display when an asset is not specifically requested. That is, loading the web page without any query string parameters will cause the gallery asset specified here to be displayed.

You can select the current gallery, which will show the root level album, or you can choose a specific album or media asset.

Users are never shown assets they do not have permission to view. When the default gallery asset is set to the current gallery, the user is shown the highest album he or she has permission to view. If an album or media asset option is specified and the user does not have permission to view it, a message appears telling the user they have insufficient permission.

NOTE: When the Allow URL navigation option is enabled, users can navigate to other albums and media assets by specifying an album or media asset ID in the query string. You may want to disable that option to prevent users from viewing other albums or media assets.

data.name: Cfg_GCS_GalleryTitleUrl_Bdy
data.value:
The URL the user will be directed to when she clicks the gallery's title text. It is optional: if not present, no link will be rendered.

Examples:

  • http://www.mysite.com
  • / (the root of the web site)
  • ~/ (the top level album)

data.name: Cfg_GCS_GalleryTitle_Bdy
data.value: The header text that appears at the top of every page.

data.name: Cfg_GCS_OverrideSettings_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies whether to override the gallery settings for this instance of the Gallery Server control on the current web page.

When disabled, the behavior of the gallery is controlled by settings on the other administration pages. When enabled, those settings are overridden by the specific values set here.

data.name: Cfg_GCS_Overview_Bdy
data.value:
The settings here apply to the specific gallery instance and page shown in the top right corner. Use this page to override the gallery-level settings specified on the other administration pages.

For example, you may want to create a gallery view where the left and right panes are disabled, but for administration purposes still want access to a page where the panes are visible. To do this, make a copy of default.aspx and name it admin.aspx. Then open default.aspx in the browser and navigate to this page. Adjust the settings to turn off the panes. Your users will see the new behavior of default.aspx but you can use admin.aspx to retain access to the original 3-pane layout.

IMPORTANT: Remember that the settings on this page override the settings on other pages. It is sometimes more appropriate to configure a setting at the gallery level rather than here at the control/page level. It is also important to understand that the settings affect this control instance, regardless of which gallery is being displayed. If you switch to another gallery on the Gallery Manager page, these settings will remain the same while the other pages will reflect the settings for the new gallery. (One exception to this rule is that if an album or media asset is specified as the default gallery asset, it is cleared after switching galleries, since the previous value is no longer valid.)

data.name: Cfg_GCS_ShowRibbonToolbar_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies whether to show the ribbon toolbar.

To hide individual buttons within the ribbon toolbar, edit the header UI template.

NOTE: Regardless of this setting, the ribbon toolbar is always VISIBLE for gallery and site administrators, even when this setting is disabled (this helps you get to the admin area to adjust settings).

data.name: Cfg_GCS_ShowAlbumBreadcrumb_Bdy
data.value: Specifies whether to show the album bread crumb links.

data.name: Cfg_GCS_ShowAlbumTreeViewForAlbum_Bdy
data.value: Specifies whether to render the left pane when an album is being displayed. By default the left pane contains a treeview of albums, but this can be modified by editing the left pane template.

data.name: Cfg_GCS_ShowAlbumTreeViewForMediaObject_Bdy
data.value: Specifies whether to render the left pane when a single media asset is being displayed. By default the left pane contains a treeview of albums, but this can be modified by editing the left pane template.

data.name: Cfg_GCS_ShowHeader_Bdy
data.value: When checked, the header area of the gallery is displayed. The header includes the gallery title, various links at the top right (login/logout, search, edit account), the ribbon toolbar, and the album breadcrumb menu.

data.name: Cfg_GCS_ShowLogin_Bdy
data.value:
When checked, controls related to user account management are shown in the top right corner of the page. These include the user name, login/logout button, and the link to the user's account page (if the option to allow users to manage their own accounts is enabled on the User Settings page). You may want to disable this feature when the audience is primarily anonymous web users without user accounts.

Administrators can always log in by navigating directly to the login page (use the query string g=login; ex: default.aspx?g=login).

data.name: Cfg_GCS_ShowMediaObjectIndexPosition_Bdy
data.value: Specifies whether to display the relative position of a media asset within an album (example: (3 of 24)). This text is shown only when a single media asset is being displayed.

data.name: Cfg_GCS_ShowMediaObjectNavigation_Bdy
data.value: Specifies whether the next and previous buttons are rendered for individual media assets. Disabling this option also disables the ability to navigate using the left and right arrow keys and swiping left and right on touchscreen devices.

data.name: Cfg_GCS_ShowMediaObjectTitle_Bdy
data.value: Specifies whether the title is displayed above individual media assets.

data.name: Cfg_GCS_ShowSearch_Bdy
data.value: Specifies whether to display the search link in the top right corner of every page.

data.name: Cfg_GCS_ViewMode_Bdy
data.value:
The view mode specifies how albums and media assets are displayed.

Album - A single album is shown, with the contents displayed as a set of thumbnail images.

Media asset - A single media asset is shown. If the URL specifies an album, then the first media asset in the album is displayed.

data.name: Cfg_showHeader_Bdy
data.value:
When checked, the header area of the gallery is displayed. The header includes the gallery title, various links at the top right (login/logout, search, edit account), the ribbon toolbar, and the album breadcrumb menu

This setting can be overridden on the Gallery Control Settings page.

data.name: Task_Delete_Album_Cannot_Delete_Contains_Default_Gallery_Object_Ex_Msg
data.value: The album {0} cannot be deleted because it is or it contains the default gallery asset in the gallery. If you want to delete this album, you must first change the default gallery asset. You can do this on the Gallery Control Settings page.

data.name: Admin_Gallery_Control_Settings_Invalid_MediaObject_Msg
data.value: Error: The media asset specified for the default gallery asset (ID# {0}) does not exist.

data.name: Msg_AlbumNotAuthorizedForUser_Dtl
data.value: You are are not authorized to view the requested album. Contact your administrator to request access.

data.name: Admin_Manage_Roles_Cannot_Save_Role_User_Would_Lose_Admin_Ability_Msg
data.value: Cannot remove requested roles. You are editing a role you are a member of, and you are attempting to remove your ability to administer this gallery. If you really want to do this, log on as another user and make the changes from that account, or make yourself a member of another role with administrative permission before modifying this role.

data.name: Admin_User_Settings_EnableUserAlbumDefaultForUser_Lbl
data.value: Automatically create user album the first time a user logs on to the gallery

data.name: Admin_User_Settings_Turn_Off_User_Album_Lbl_Bdy
data.value:
This action updates the profiles for existing user accounts in the current gallery. Specifically, it sets the EnableUserAlbum profile setting to False for all users.

If a user album exists for an account, it will be automatically deleted the next time he or she logs in.

WARNING: Clicking this button will cause the permanent deletion of user albums for all accounts in this gallery!

data.name: Admin_User_Settings_Turn_Off_User_Album_Lbl_Text
data.value: Turn off user albums for all existing accounts

data.name: Admin_User_Settings_Turn_On_User_Album_Lbl_Bdy
data.value:
This action updates the profiles for existing user accounts in the current gallery. Specifically, it sets the EnableUserAlbum profile setting to True for all users.

This will cause a user album to be created for a user the next time he or she logs in if it does not already exist.

data.name: Admin_User_Settings_Turn_On_User_Album_Lbl_Text
data.value: Turn on user albums for all existing accounts

data.name: Admin_User_Settings_User_Album_Existing_Accounts_Lbl_Bdy
data.value:
These buttons, which are only available when user albums have been enabled at the gallery level, enable or disable user albums at the user level. Click the Enable All button to turn on the user album for each account, including those where the user turned off their user album on their account page or an administrator turned off the user’s user album on the Users page. Similarly, click the Disable All button to turn off the user album for all accounts.

After clicking one of these buttons, an administrator (or user, if users are allowed to manage their own account) can selectively enable or disable the user album for individual accounts.

IMPORTANT: Clicking either of the buttons below will not immediately create or delete any user albums, but the next time each user logs on, the validation logic will create or delete the user's album based on the value of their profile setting. When the user's profile specifies a disabled user album and a user album currently exists, the album - and its contents - are permanently deleted. Use with caution!

Note: To improve performance, user profiles are stored in the server's session, which means currently logged on users will not see the effect of you enabling or disabling profiles until the next time their profile is retrieved from the data store. To force your change to take immediate effect, restart the application.

data.name: Admin_User_Settings_User_Album_Existing_Accounts_Lbl_Hdr
data.value: Change user album setting in existing accounts

data.name: Cfg_enableUserAlbumDefaultForUser_Bdy
data.value:
Indicates whether a user album is automatically created the first time a user logs on.

Specifically, this setting defines the default value of the EnableUserAlbum setting in the user's profile record.

A user can enable or disable his or her user album on the account settings page. An administrator can access this setting for any user on the Manage Users page.

Note that if you have turned off the option to allow a user to manage their account (see below), then only an administrator can enable or disable a user's album.

This setting applies only when user albums are enabled.

data.name: Admin_User_Settings_Cannot_Enable_User_Albums_In_Read_Only_Gallery
data.value: Cannot enable user albums in a read-only gallery.

data.name: Admin_Backup_Restore_Db_Successfully_Restored_AppNotRecycled_Msg
data.value: The gallery data has been successfully restored, but the application could not be automatically restarted. Before continuing, recycle the application pool to ensure the application is properly initialized.

data.name: Admin_Site_Settings_AllowGalleryAdminToManageUsersAndRoles_Label
data.value: Allow gallery admins to manage users and roles

data.name: Admin_Site_Settings_AllowGalleryAdminToViewAllUsersAndRoles_Label
data.value: Allow gallery admins to view users/roles who do not have access to current gallery

data.name: Admin_User_Settings_Cannot_Enable_Self_Registration_Msg
data.value: Cannot enable self-registration. The site administrator has disabled the ability for a gallery administrator to manage users and roles.

data.name: Cfg_allowGalleryAdminToManageUsersAndRole_Bdy
data.value:
When enabled, gallery administrators are allowed to create, edit, and delete users and roles. When disabled, gallery admins cannot access the Manage Users and Manage Roles pages, nor can they enable the self registration feature.

This setting affects only gallery administrators - site administrators and regular users are unaffected.

data.name: Cfg_allowGalleryAdminToManageUsersAndRole_Hdr
data.value: Allow gallery admins to manage users and roles

data.name: Cfg_allowGalleryAdminViewAllUsersAndRoles_Bdy
data.value:
When enabled, gallery administrators are allowed to view users and roles who do not have access to the current gallery. This option affects any area where users and roles are displayed, such as the Manage Users, Manage Roles and User Settings pages.

This option must be enabled for a gallery administrator to be able to give existing users access to a gallery.

Note that even when this setting is enabled, a gallery administrator cannot perform any task that would violate the security scope. For example, a gallery administrator for gallery A cannot give a user access to gallery B unless the admin is also an administrator for gallery B, regardless of this setting.

This setting affects only gallery administrators - site administrators and regular users are unaffected.

data.name: Cfg_allowGalleryAdminViewAllUsersAndRoles_Hdr
data.value: Allow gallery admins to view all users and roles

data.name: Admin_MediaObjects_EnableAlbumZipDownload_Label
data.value: Allow child albums to be downloaded

data.name: Cfg_enableAlbumZipDownload_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies whether users can download entire albums in a ZIP archive. When an album is selected, any child albums it contains are also included. This can require a great deal of processing power if the user has selected a top-level album that contains many child albums.

Disable this option to reduce the impact a user can have on server performance.

When disabled, only media assets in the current album can be downloaded.

data.name: Cfg_enableAlbumZipDownload_Hdr
data.value: Allow child albums to be downloaded

data.name: Admin_Albums_AutoSyncIntervalMinutes_Lbl
data.value: Check for new files every {blank} minutes
data.comment: <2011.02.21> Used in error message when an invalid value is entered

data.name: Admin_Albums_AutoSyncIntervalMinutes_Lbl1
data.comment: <2011.02.21> A textbox is placed between this text and the text in Admin_Albums_AutoSyncIntervalMinutes_Lbl2

data.name: Admin_Albums_AutoSyncIntervalMinutes_Lbl2
data.comment: <2011.02.21> A textbox is placed between this text and the text in Admin_Albums_AutoSyncIntervalMinutes_Lbl1

data.name: Admin_Albums_EnableAutoSync_Lbl
data.value: Automatically synchronize gallery with media assets directory

data.name: Admin_Albums_EnableRemoteSync_Lbl
data.value: Allow external applications to synchronize gallery

data.name: Admin_Albums_RemoteAccess_Msg
data.value: Use this URL to remotely invoke a synchronization (change query string parameters as required):

data.name: Cfg_autoSyncIntervalMinutes_Bdy
data.value:
The interval, in minutes, between synchronizations.

Note: This feature depends on periodic browser requests. If the site is infrequently accessed, the intervals between synchronizations may be longer than the value specified here.

data.name: Cfg_enableAutoSync_Bdy
data.value: Indicates whether to periodically synchronize the current gallery at a user-specified interval.

data.name: Cfg_enableRemoteSync_Bdy
data.value: Indicates whether external applications are allowed to initiate a synchronization. When enabled, an URL is enabled that starts a synchronization with the parameters specified in the query string. The URL can be invoked with a GET request.

data.name: Cfg_remoteAccessPassword_Bdy
data.value: Specifies the password to use when invoking the web service methods. This is required to help ensure that only authorized users are able to invoke the methods.

data.name: Admin_Albums_LastAutoSync_Never_Lbl
data.comment: <2011.02.21> Text to display when an auto-sync has never been performed

data.name: Cfg_metadataDisplaySettings_Bdy
data.value:
Each album and media asset in the gallery has several properties, collectively called metadata. This page lets one configure their appearance and behavior.

Refer to the individual tool tips for more details about each setting.

data.name: Cfg_jQueryScriptPath_Bdy
data.value:
The path to the jQuery script file. The path may be:

  • Relative to the root of the web application. Ex: "~/Scripts/jquery-3.1.1.min.js"
  • A full URL. Ex: "//code.jquery.com/jquery-3.1.1.min.js"

If the web application already uses jQuery and is adding the jQuery script reference through another mechanism, specify a blank string for this setting.

data.name: Cfg_jQueryUIScriptPath_Bdy
data.value:
The path to the jQuery UI script file. The path may be:

  • Relative to the root of the web application. Ex: "~/gs/script/jquery-ui.min.js"
  • A full URL. Ex: "//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jqueryui/1.12.1/jquery-ui.min.js"

If the web application already uses jQuery UI and is adding the script reference through another mechanism, specify a blank string for this setting.

data.name: Cfg_jQueryMigrateScriptPath_Hdr
data.value: Path to jQuery Migrate script file

data.name: Cfg_jQueryMigrateScriptPath_Bdy
data.value:
The path to the jQuery Migrate script file. This file is used to provide backward compatibility when using jQuery 1.9 and higher. It is required by several plug-ins that have not yet been updated for 1.9+. The path may be:

  • Relative to the root of the web application. Ex: "~/gs/script/jquery-migrate.js"
  • A full URL. Ex: "//code.jquery.com/jquery-migrate-3.0.0.min.js"

If the script is no longer necessary, leave this path empty.

data.name: Cfg_jQueryUIScriptPath_Hdr
data.value: Path to jQuery UI script file

data.name: Admin_Site_Settings_InvalidJQueryPath
data.value: The specified jQuery path does not exist

data.name: Admin_Site_Settings_FFmpeg_Info_Bdy
data.value:
This value indicates whether ffmpeg.exe was discovered in the application's bin directory. FFmpeg is an open source utility used to create thumbnail images from videos and encode video and audio to other formats.

This utility is installed separately as part of the Gallery Server Binary Pack, available for free from galleryserverpro.com.

Note: The application must be running in full trust to execute this utility.

data.name: Admin_Site_Settings_ImageMagick_Info_Bdy
data.value:
Specify the path to the directory containing the ImageMagick convert.exe application. The path may be:

  • (Preferred) A full path to the directory containing the ImageMagick installation. Example: "C:\Program Files\ImageMagick-6.9.3-Q16"
  • Relative to the root of the web application. Example: "\bin" refers to the bin directory of the current web application

ImageMagick is an open source utility used to generate images from several media types, including PDF, AI, TXT, PSD, EPS, TIF, NEF and CR2 files.

This utility is installed separately as either a stand-alone ImageMagick client installation (preferred) or as part of the Gallery Server Binary Pack, available for free from galleryserverpro.com. Refer to the Admin Guide for details.

This is optional. When ImageMagick is not available, we'll gracefully fall back to using generic images for unsupported file types.

Note: The application must be running in full trust to execute this utility.

Note: ImageMagick requires that GhostScript be installed for certain operations. GhostScript can be found in the Binary Pack and at ghostscript.com.

data.name: Admin_Site_Settings_DataProvider_Compact_Bdy
data.value:
Microsoft recommends periodically running this command to maintain the health and performance of your SQL CE database. In addition, it can repair some types of corruption. The following tasks are performed:

  • Indexes are recreated.
  • Tables are defragmented.
  • Identity column values are recalculated based on existing data.
  • If data corruption is found, a repair is automatically attempted.

data.name: UC_MediaObjectView_Media_Object_Being_Processed_Text
data.value: The item is being processed and is not yet ready for viewing.

data.name: Admin_VidAudOther_EncoderSettings_InsufficientTrust_Msg
data.value: Not available. Requires full trust, but application is running at {0} trust.

data.name: Admin_VidAudOther_EncoderSettings_FFmpegMissing_Msg
data.value: Not available. FFmpeg.exe not found in bin directory. Install the Gallery Server Binary Pack.

data.name: Admin_VidAudOther_EncoderSettings_Overview_Bdy
data.value:
You can create web-friendly versions of video and audio files when they are added to the gallery or during synchronization.

The settings in this section are used to match video and audio files based on the file extension of the original media asset, and then create an encoded version based on the provided arguments. The order is important, as the gallery applies the first match it finds. That means you want the All video and All audio selectors last. If an encoding fails, the next matching encoding is tried.

The arguments you specify are passed to FFmpeg and can contain any valid FFmpeg options. The following replacement tokens are supported: {SourceFilePath}, {DestinationFilePath}, {Width} (an integer without units), {Height} (an integer without units), {AspectRatio} (the aspect ratio of a video, such as 1.33 or 1.78), {BinPath} (full path to app's bin directory), and {GalleryResourcesPath} (full path to Gallery Server's resources directory).

The {Width} and {Height} parameters apply to videos and are replaced by the width and height of the original video file. If these values cannot be determined, the default width and height values specified in the General section above are used.

To tell the encoder to skip a particular file type, enter an empty set of FFmpeg arguments.

The default encoder settings for video attempt to create a web-optimized MP4 H.264 version. If that fails, a Flash Video (FLV) version is attempted. Audio files are encoded to M4A. MP3, M4A, and FLV files are not encoded since they are already web-friendly.

To force the encoder to run against existing media assets, perform a synchronization and use the Rebuild optimized versions option to overwrite any existing encoded version.

The encoder requires that the application is running at full trust and the FFmpeg.exe utility exists in the application's bin directory. FFmpeg can be found at ffmpeg.org or, for your convenience, in the Gallery Server Binary Pack.

data.name: Admin_VidAudOther_EncoderTimeout_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies the timeout value for the encoder in milliseconds. If the encoder doesn't complete in the specified amount of time, the encoding is aborted.

Specify the smallest amount of time necessary to handle your encoding needs. In cases where the encoder has hung and does not respond to cancel requests, the timeout is the only way to force an exit to kill any processor load it is putting on the web server.

The default value is 15 minutes (900,000 milleseconds).

data.name: Admin_VidAudOther_EncoderSettings_Tip
data.value: Tip: An empty argument means that file type should be ignored (NOT encoded).

data.name: Admin_Templates_Cannot_Modify_Default_Tmpl_Msg
data.value: Cannot persist changes: You cannot modify or delete the default template.

data.name: Admin_Templates_Cannot_Save_Tmpl_Insufficient_License_Msg
data.value:
Cannot persist changes: You must be running Gallery Server Enterprise or higher to edit UI templates. Enter a qualifying license key to enable this feature.

You can, however, switch templates by enabling or disabling albums on the Target Albums tab.

data.name: Admin_Media_Templates_Cannot_Delete_Default_Tmpl_Msg

data.name: Admin_Media_Templates_Cannot_Save_No_Default_Tmpl_Msg

data.name: Admin_Templates_Cannot_Save_Duplicate_Name_Msg

data.name: Admin_Templates_Cannot_Save_No_Tmpl_Msg

data.value: Cannot create role: A role already exists with the name you entered.

data.value: An error has occurred. See the event log for details.

data.value: Your gallery has been successfully synchronized.

data.name: Cfg_GCS_ShowCenterPane_Bdy
data.value: Specifies whether to render the center pane. By default, the center pane contains a thumbnail list of album contents or a single media asset.

data.name: Cfg_GCS_ShowRightPane_Bdy
data.value: Specifies whether to render the right pane. By default, the right pane contains detailed information about an album or media asset.

data.name: Cfg_GCS_SlideShowType_Bdy
data.value: Specifies the type of image slideshow to use. A full screen slideshow takes advantage of the full browser window. The inline slideshow preserves the current image size and page layout. Use the inline option when you do not want the slideshow interfering with other page elements.

data.name: Cfg_GCS_TreeviewNavigateUrl_Bdy
data.value: Specifies an URL to navigate to when an album node is clicked. When left blank, clicking an album node shows the requested album in the current page. You may want to specify another page when you are using the treeview as a menu to take users to another page.

data.name: Admin_MediaTmpl_Overview_Bdy
data.value:
This page gives you control over the exact rendering of media files in the browser.

For example, H.264 MP4 videos are viewed using the HTML5 video element in most browsers, but IE 1-8 and Opera require a plug-in. You can change this behavior on this page.

Media templates are application-wide and cannot be tailored to individual galleries.

data.name: Admin_MediaTmpl_BrowserId_Bdy
data.value:
The browser ID is used to match a user's browser to particular media template. Each MIME type must have one template defined for the "default" browser ID; this will match all browsers. Add additional browser ID entries to target individual browsers. The gallery automatically chooses the most specific template available.

For example, if three templates are specified having browser IDs of default, IE, and IE1to8, a user with IE7 will match the IE1to8 template, a user with IE10 will match the IE template, and other browsers will match the default template.

View a list of valid browser ID values recognized by .NET 4.0. In addition, the values IE1to8 and ChromeAndroid are defined.

data.name: Admin_MediaTmpl_MimeType_Bdy
data.value: Each MIME type is mapped to a file extension that can be seen on the Media Object Types page. Use a wildcard (for example video/*) to map a template to an entire MIME type category.

data.name: Admin_MediaTmpl_Tmpl_Bdy
data.value:
Specify the HTML or JavaScript to be sent to the browser when displaying a media file having this MIME type. The script is executed after the HTML is rendered. Below is a list of replacement parameters that may be used. Refer to the Admin Guide for more details.

  • {MediaObjectUrl} - The URL to the media asset. Ex: /gs/handler/getmedia.ashx?moid=5&dt=2&g=1
  • {MediaObjectAbsoluteUrlNoHandler} - An URL that points directly to the media file. Ex: /gallery/videos/birthdayvideo.wmv
  • {MediaObjectRelativeUrlNoHandler} - An URL that is relative to the media assets directory that points directly to the media file. Ex: /videos/birthdayvideo.wmv
  • {MimeType} - The MIME type of the media asset. Ex: image/jpeg, video/mp4
  • {Width} - The width, in pixels. Ex: 640
  • {Height} - The height, in pixels. Ex: 640
  • {Title} - The media asset title.
  • {TitleNoHtml} - The title with any HTML removed.
  • {AutoPlay} - "autoplay" if video and audio should play on page load; otherwise an empty string.
  • {AutoStartMediaObjectText} - "false" or "true", depending on whether video and audio should play on page load.
  • {AutoStartMediaObjectInt} - 0 or 1, depending on whether video and audio should play on page load.
  • {GalleryPath} - The path, relative to the web site root, to the directory containing the Gallery Server files. Ex: /dev/gallery/gs
  • {HostUrl} - The URI scheme, DNS host name or IP address, and port number for the current application. Ex: http://www.site.com
  • {UniqueId} - A string that can be used to uniquely identify a DOM element. Ex: gsp_1c135176ed

data.name: Admin_UiTemplate_Overview_Bdy
data.value:
The gallery is rendered from jsRender templates defined on this page. The templates are divided into these sections:

  • Header - The top portion of the page.
  • Left pane - The album tree on the left.
  • Right pane - The properties window on the right.
  • Album - The view to display in the center pane when displaying an album (that is, when the 'aid' querystring parameter is in the URL)
  • Media object - The view to display in the center pane when displaying a media asset (that is, when the 'moid' querystring parameter is in the URL)

NOTE: Administration and task pages such as the synchronization and add assets pages are not rendered from UI templates.

UI templates are bound to a rich set of gallery data that is included in the HTML sent to the browser. To reduce the complexity of JavaScript stored in the templates and to improve performance, the script in these templates delegate their actions to JavaScript in external files. You can force the browser to use unminified versions of these files by setting debug to "true" in the web.config file in the root of the web application. See the Admin Guide for full documentation for the client API and tips for modifying the templates.

You cannot edit the default template. Instead, make a copy of the default template and edit that one. This way you can always revert back to the original if desired.

You can create several templates, each targeted to specific albums. For example, you might have an album of PDF files that you want rendered as a list view instead of a thumbnail.

WARNING: Editing these templates are for advanced users with HTML and JavaScript skills. Remember that much of the UI layout and behavior can be controlled by changing settings on the other administration pages. Whenever possible, change a setting there before resorting to a UI template change.

When upgrading to a new version, Gallery Server often performs a search and replace on the changed parts of UI templates. If you customized a template, the search may not find the expected match and your template will not receive the updated HTML/script. Therefore, review your custom templates after each upgrade. In some cases you may need to copy from the default template and re-apply your customization.

data.name: Admin_UiTemplate_Target_Album_Bdy
data.value:
Specify the album or albums this template applies to. When multiple templates are specified for the same album, the template that is defined closest to the album is preferred.

For example, if the default template targets all albums and a second template targets a child album, the second template will be used for the child album and its children.

data.name: Admin_UiTemplate_Tmpl_Bdy
data.value:
Specify the HTML or JavaScript to be sent to the browser. Both the HTML and JavaScript templates accept any valid jsRender syntax.

The templates are rendered through this process:

  1. The HTML and JavaScript templates are sent to the browser in two script tags with type='text/x-jsrender'.
  2. The content of the JavaScript template is passed through the jsRender engine.
  3. This output is executed in a Function constructor.
  4. The JavaScript is responsible for running the HTML template through the rendering engine and inserting the generated HTML into the web page's DOM structure.

data.name: Admin_Css_Overview_Bdy
data.value:
Use this page to provide a custom stylesheet implementation. For example, you may wish to override the default fonts, colors, padding, or other styling.

The styles you specify here are rendered in the head section of the page after the other CSS files.

data.name: Cfg_skin_Bdy
data.value:
The skin specifies the name of the directory where the icons and CSS files that control the look and feel of the gallery exist. By default these are stored at gs\skins\.

If you wish to modify the skin, it is recommended that you first make a copy of the existing skin. This makes it easier to revert to the original configuration if desired. Use File Explorer or an FTP tool to copy the skin directory.

Note that the skin only defines icon images and CSS styles. If you wish to modify the layout of the UI or other changes, consider these administration features:

  • Media templates - Defines how media files are rendered in the browser.
  • UI templates - Defines jsRender templates for generating HTML for the header, left, center and right panes of the user interface.

data.name: Cfg_slideShowType_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies the type of image slideshow to use. A full screen slideshow takes advantage of the full browser window. The inline slideshow preserves the current image size and page layout. Use the inline option when you do not want the slideshow interfering with other page elements.

This setting can be overridden on the Gallery Control Settings page.

data.name: Cfg_metadataDateTimeFormatString_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies the .NET format string to use for displaying the date-related metadata items DateAdded, DateFileCreated, DateFileCreatedUtc, DateFileLastModified, DateFileLastModifiedUtc, and DatePictureTaken.

To update existing meta values after changing this setting, run the re-extraction task in the grid below for each meta item you want to update.

Any format string recognized by the .NET Framework may be used. Here are some common ones:

PatternExample
M/dd/yyyy6/25/2013
MMM dd, yyyy h:mm:ss ttJun 25, 2013 7:06:32 PM
dddd, MMMM dd, yyyy HH:mmFriday, June 25, 2013 19:06
yyyy-MM-dd hh:mm:ss tt2013-06-25 07:06:32 PM

data.name: Site_UserNameIsDuplicate
data.value: User name is already in use. Choose another.

data.name: Cfg_allowAnonymousRating_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies whether anonymous users are allowed to give a rating to media assets. Disable this option to require that users be logged on to be able to rate an object.

When the rating metadata item is disabled on the metadata page, users are never allowed to rate an object, regardless of this setting.

data.name: Cfg_allowAnonymousRating_Hdr
data.value: Allow anonymous rating of media assets

data.value: Uploaded file is too large. The maximum upload size is {0} bytes, but the uploaded size was {1} bytes.

data.name: Msg_ObjectsBeingProcessedAsyncronously_Dtl

data.name: Msg_CannotTransferObjectInsufficientPermission_Dtl

data.name: Task_Modify_Asset_Cannot_Modify_MediaPathIsReadOnly
data.value: The item(s) cannot be modified or deleted because the gallery is configured for read-only access.

data.name: Admin_Albums_UpdateSortStarted_Msg
data.value: Existing albums are being sorted and should be finished soon.

data.name: Admin_Albums_UpdateSort_Bdy
data.value:
When selected, all existing albums are updated to use the sort property and direction specified above and are immediately resorted based on these values.

CAUTION: This option resorts all albums in the gallery, so be sure this is what you want.

data.name: UC_MoView_NoSs_Bdy
data.value: There are no images in this album

data.name: UC_MoView_Tb_Share_DownloadAlbum_Link_Tt
data.value: Get a ZIP file containing this album

data.name: Site_Tag_Tree_Node_Tt
data.value: Click to view all items tagged with {0}

data.name: Admin_Metadata_Gd_Album_Bdy
data.value:
Enable this option to activate the property for albums. When selected, the meta item will be generated when an album is created or when the re-extraction task is triggered. It also specifies whether the item is visible.

For example, disabling the Tags property will immediately hide the tags from the user. That is, they won't be included in the client data sent to the browser and they won't be shown in the right pane.

In addition, a database record for this tag will not be created for new albums. If an admin re-extracts this meta item, existing album tags in the database will be deleted.

For best performance, turn off all unnecessary properties.

data.name: Admin_Metadata_Gd_DefValue_Bdy
data.value:
The default value specifies the initial value for a meta item when it is added to the gallery or when it is re-extracted. It can be plain text, HTML, a replacement parameter (e.g. {Title}), or a combination.

Replacement parameters are mapped to specific metadata extraction behavior. For example, {Title} maps to a function that determines a title by looking in various places:

  • For an album, the directory name is used.
  • For images, the title is extracted from internal metadata, defaulting to the filename if not present.
  • For external items such as YouTube videos, the user-entered title is used.

The list of valid replacement parameters is in the Name column of the grid. Note that some properties may not be mapped to custom behavior and will result in an empty string (e.g. Custom1).

EXAMPLES

  • Enter a custom color
  • {Title}
  • {Title} ({ExposureTime}, {FNumber})
  • <a href='http://maps.google.com/maps?q={GpsLatitude},{GpsLongitude}' target='_blank' title='View map'>{GpsLocation}</a>

data.name: Admin_Metadata_Gd_DisName_Bdy
data.value:
This is the name of the meta property displayed to the user. It's sent to the client in the Desc property of the MetaItem object.

Changes to this property take effect immediately - there is no need to re-extract the property or synchronize.

data.name: Admin_Metadata_Gd_Editable_Bdy
data.value:
When enabled, users belonging to a role with edit permission can edit the meta property value. Property editing is typically done by clicking the item in the right pane.

Click the cell to cycle through three possible settings: (1) Not editable (2) Editable with plain text editor (3) Editable with HTML editor.

If a user does not belong to a role with edit permission, editing is not allowed, regardless of this setting.

NOTE: The free version does not support the HTML editor. Upgrade to one of the commercial versions to enable this feature.

data.name: Admin_Metadata_Gd_Id_Bdy
data.value:
This is an integer that uniquely identifies the media asset property and is included in the client data sent to the browser. It's stored in the MTypeId property of the MetaItem object.

This ID is a convenient way to find and reference particular meta properties from within UI templates.

For example, the right pane UI template uses these IDs to help construct the desired HTML for each meta item.

data.name: Admin_Metadata_Gd_Media_Bdy
data.value:
Enable this option to activate the property for media assets. When selected, the meta item will be generated when a media asset is created or when the re-extraction task is triggered. It also specifies whether the item is visible.

For example, disabling the Tags property will immediately hide the tags from the user. That is, they won't be included in the client data sent to the browser and they won't be shown in the right pane.

In addition, a database record for this tag will not be created for new media assets. If an admin re-extracts this meta item, existing media asset tags in the database will be deleted.

For best performance, turn off all unnecessary properties.

data.name: Admin_Metadata_Gd_Media_Hdr
data.value: Apply meta property to media asset

data.name: Admin_Metadata_Gd_Rebuild_Bdy
data.value:
These buttons update the metadata values in the database with new ones extracted from the original file and based on the default value and visibility settings of the property.

This is useful for quickly creating or deleting meta records for all items in the gallery.

For example, one can enable the Custom1 property for media assets, give it a display name (e.g. "Color"), make it editable, and then invoke this task to generate records for all media assets. Once complete, the new property is visible in the right pane and editable by anyone belonging to a role having edit permission.

This task does not modify the original media files.

Note that this task runs asynchronously on the server and can take a long time for large galleries. The event log will contain a notification when it is finished.

PERFORMANCE TIP

If you don't need certain meta items, turn them off and run this task for each property to remove those records from the database. Meta items are turned off by unchecking the album and media settings in this grid.

data.name: Admin_Metadata_Gd_WriteToFiles_Bdy
data.value:
These buttons immediately write the metadata stored in the database for a particular property to all the original media files in the gallery. This is especially useful for those who have invested time adding tags, titles, and other properties when using a Gallery Server version that did not support metadata file writing (such as all versions prior to 4.0 and the free version of 4+).

Buttons are shown only for those properties that support metadata writing.

Read the tooltip in the 'Write' column for more information.

Note that this task runs asynchronously on the server and can take a long time for large galleries. The event log will contain a notification when it is finished.

CAUTION: This task modifies the original media files and has the potential to remove metadata and/or cause slight degradation in image quality. For example, if you've deleted tags in your gallery, those tags will be deleted from the original image file. And if you've added metadata, the image file may need to be re-encoded with padding to make room for the data.

data.name: Admin_Metadata_Gd_Sort_Bdy
data.value:
Media asset properties are displayed in the right pane in the same order as shown in this table.

Drag a row to a new position to change the order.

data.name: Admin_Metadata_Gd_Writable_Bdy
data.value:
When enabled, changes to meta properties are written back to the original media file. Currently, this includes EXIF, XMP, and IPTC support for JPG and JPEG files. Meta writing to other file types is not supported.

When possible, all relevant EXIF, XMP, and IPTC properties are updated. For example, caption changes are written to EXIF XPComment, XMP Description, and IPTC Caption fields.

Note: The IPTC properties (e.g. IPTC headline, IPTC caption, etc.) in this list are written ONLY to the corresponding field. For example, a user editing the IPTC Caption property will update only that IPTC field, not the related EXIF or XMP fields.

If a gallery is configured as read-only, the original file is not updated even when this setting is enabled.

Not all properties can be written to the file. Those that are unsupported have a special icon indicating that status.

CAUTION: Often an image file must be re-encoded with additional padding to make room for new metadata. When this occurs, the image is encoded at the JPG quality setting defined on the Image Settings page (default is 95). This is a lossy process that causes a slight degradation to the image. It can also cause an increase in the file size of images that were previously encoded at a lower quality setting. For most users the change is not noticeable and worth the benefit of having metadata preserved in the original file. But if you find it unacceptable, leave metadata writing disabled.

data.name: Admin_Metadata_Gd_Writable_Hdr
data.value: Write changed metadata back to file

data.name: Task_Transfer_Objects_Cannot_Transfer_File_NotFound_Dtl
data.value: The file {0} no longer exists. Either replace it or synchronize the containing album to update the database records.

data.name: Admin_MediaQueue_Overview_Bdy
data.value: This page shows you the status of the media queue processor, which runs on a background thread performing time-intensive operations such as video transcoding and image processing. It also lets you cancel a pending or current operation, review the details of a completed task, or remove it.

data.name: Admin_Gallery_Control_Settings_MediaViewSize_Label
data.value: When viewing a single media asset, use this size:

data.name: Cfg_mediaViewSize_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies the default size to display when viewing a single media asset. This option can be overridden on the Gallery Control Settings page and by a user in the ribbon menu.

When the original size is selected, the media asset is scaled down as necessary in the browser to reduce horizontal scrolling.

TIP: Remember that your original files may be very large and take some time to download, resulting in undesirable behavior in low bandwidth environments. You may also encounter issues if your original files are not capable of being displayed in a web browser. We suggest leaving this setting at the 'optimized' size to ensure best performance.

Users who do not have access to the original version of your media assets are never able to view the original file. For example, if this setting is set to Original and a user does not have permission to view them, they are shown the compressed versions instead.

data.name: Cfg_GCS_MediaViewSize_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies the default size to display when viewing a single media asset. This option can be overridden by a user in the ribbon menu.

When the original size is selected, the media asset is scaled down as necessary in the browser to reduce horizontal scrolling.

TIP: Remember that your original files may be very large and take some time to download, resulting in undesirable behavior in low bandwidth environments. You may also encounter issues if your original files are not capable of being displayed in a web browser. We suggest leaving this setting at the 'optimized' size to ensure best performance.

Users who do not have access to the original version of your media assets are never able to view the original file. For example, if this setting is set to Original and a user does not have permission to view them, they are shown the compressed versions instead.

data.name: RbnDelDbRcrdsTtDtl
data.value:
Use this option to remove the selected assets from the gallery while preserving the underlying directory or original media file.

TIP: Items deleted with this option will be re-imported the next time the album is synchronized. You can permanently prevent a file or directory from being imported using one of these tricks:

  • Uncheck the file extension on the File Types page (Settings tab).
  • Mark the file or directory as hidden with a file utility such as File Explorer.
  • Edit the NTFS permissions on the IIS application pool identity so that it does not have access to the file or directory.

data.name: RbnDelOrgTtDtl
data.value:
Use this option to delete the original media files, preserving the thumbnail and web-optimized versions.

When selected, the estimated savings will be shown below the thumbnail image. (If you are viewing a single media asset, switch to the thumbnail view to see the savings.)

This option is useful when you want to free up disk space on the server and don't mind losing access to the original, high resolution media file.

WARNING: The original media files will be permanently deleted. If you subsequently re-extract one or more metadata properties (on the Metadata Settings page), you may lose the data you extracted from the originals if they are not present in the web-optimized version.

data.name: RbnThmbTtDtl
data.value:
Each album has an image that is used to visually represent that album. Typically this is one of the media assets within the album, but you can assign any media asset to be the thumbnail image for an album.

Select a thumbnail image or navigate to an individual media asset in the center pane, then do one of the following:

  • Click the Assign Thumbnail ribbon button. The current album will be updated.
  • In the album tree within the thumbnail options dialog, select the album to be assigned a new thumbnail image.

data.name: RbnDelDbOnly
data.value: Delete only the database records; keep the files/directories

data.name: RbnDelOrg
data.value: Delete the original files to free up disk space

data.name: RbnThmbTt
data.value: Assign selected media asset as thumbnail image for album

data.name: RbnGsEntTt
data.value: Requires Gallery Server Enterprise or higher

data.name: RbnGsHmTt
data.value: Requires Gallery Server Home & Nonprofit or higher

data.name: RbnSecPvtAbm
data.value: Hide this album from anonymous users

data.name: RbnSyncTt
data.value: Synchronize the media files on the server with the database

data.name: MyAccount_ResetProfile_Bdy
data.value:
We remember settings you select and apply them the next time you visit. Use this link to revert to default settings.

These are the profile settings that are cleared:

  • Media asset size (original or web-optimized)
  • Slideshow style (full screen or inline)
  • Slideshow loop preference (on or off)
  • Width of the left and right panes

data.name: Admin_MediaObjects_SlideShowLoop_Tt
data.value: When enabled, the slideshow loops indefinitely

data.name: RbnOrgTt
data.value: View original, high resolution media asset

data.name: Admin_MediaQueue_Ffmpeg_Not_Installed_Bdy
data.value:
This page shows the status of background media processing tasks such as the generation of web-friendly versions of your video assets. These tasks require ffmpeg.exe, which is not included in a default installation.

You can find it in the free Gallery Server Binary Pack. Copy ffmpeg.exe to the bin directory of the web application on the server.

While you're at it, install the other tools in the Binary Pack to give you additional features like RAW image processing and thumbnail generation for more file types. Trust us - it's worth it!

data.name: RbnRplTtDtl
data.value:
You can replace the original file for a media asset with a new file you select here. The existing ID and most metadata is preserved.

Use this function when you edit the original file outside of the gallery. This includes image/video edits in a third party editor and updates to PDFs and other documents.

When you upload a replacement file, the original file is deleted and the new file takes its place. The following file-related meta properties are refreshed: width, height, dimensions, orientation, file name, file size, audio format, video format, bit rate, and duration. In addition, new thumbnail and web-optimized versions are generated.

The replacement file does not need to have the same file name as the original. However, it does need to be the same general type of media asset. For example, an image can only be replaced with another image, a video with a video, and so on.

This task does not support re-extracting all metadata from the replacement file. If you wish to do this, delete the media asset from the album and add it as a new asset. Keep in mind that this approach generates a new ID.
